text: Hey everyone, I just wanted to put in here that I am part of an Indian community known as Promote Your Brand and they are hosting a Fashion Week in Delhi and there will be a lobby filled with top brands such Tom Ford, White Hat Jr., Jindals and lot more. If anyone is interested in participating or lead sponsoring this event, you can let me know about that. Also if you need any other details regarding the same, I would be happy to send them over DM. Thank you

text:
Those of you who freelance/work on a consulting basis:
How do you deal with feeling like you might be charging too much for your services, even though you know how much time it takes to create and deliver what you provide?
Do you ever feel like you should be working _all the time_ even when you don't have a full slate of clients?
How do you deal with the guilt of _not_ working all the time?
And, if you're willing to share, what do you typically charge for a well-researched long-form article (2k+ words) that includes keyword research?

elements.text:

Do you ever feel like you should be working

even when you don't have a full slate of clients?
How do you deal with the guilt of

working all the time?
And, if you're willing to share, what do you typically charge for a well-researched long-form article (2k+ words) that includes keyword research?

text:
Hey Theresa, very valid questions and I'm keen to hear what others think. I can only speak from my experience of doing a bit of consulting before. When I started I charged what I now think was an average rate but the important thing was that I was able to build a relationship with the client over time, which in turn lead to a steady stream of work, successes, referrals and recommendations for more work from other clients. Not recommending you charge less, but don't underestimate the compounding effect of the relationship.
And yes, I did feel guilty when I was not working _all the time_ then. How did I deal with the guilt? Badly:slightly_smiling_face: . I've learnt over the last year to relax a little but that's just me.

Have you considered charging an hourly rate, especially if you're thinking of SEO-based long-form work, which often take a bit of time to show results?

then. How did I deal with the guilt? Badly

. I've learnt over the last year to relax a little but that's just me.

Have you considered charging an hourly rate, especially if you're thinking of SEO-based long-form work, which often take a bit of time to show results?

text: Oh Theresa! It's the ongoing struggle of being a consultant. I've been doing this for 7 years and I've recently been feeling like work is "slow" when actually all that happened is my kid went to fulltime daycare and I gained TIME. Imagine having time! Time to grocery shop or get an eyebrow wax or take a walk. But the whole benefit of being a freelancer is having that flexibility. You really need to de-couple the idea that sitting/working = money. People are paying you for your time... but also your many years of experience.

People are paying you for your time... but also your many years of experience.

text:
<@U02C37J4X5K> I find that charging per project or on a monthly retainer is more stable for me, and overall seems to be more accurate. Charging an hourly rate doesn't reflect the quality of the content I'm creating -- and I don't say that to brag in any way. I've just done a lot of research on content around the internet, and there's very little that really counts as high-quality except for what those of us who really pour ourselves into our work put out.

I also simultaneously offer strategy consulting and other services that would be hard to price by the hour, given that the work doesn't have definable time chunks; rather, it's several different bits that come together over the course of the project.

text: True that about the quality of content today. Yes I meant something like a retainer instead of a per-article rate. That way you can cover different types of services.

text: Thanks for posting this Theresa :slightly_smiling_face: I struggle with this too... I've been so conditioning to think that work = typing and everything else is just mucking around, it's really hard to make that mindset shift now that I'm running my own business!

elements.text: I struggle with this too... I've been so conditioning to think that work = typing and everything else is just mucking around, it's really hard to make that mindset shift now that I'm running my own business!

text: <@U02AR2XSN1M>  Truth! It’s especially hard when you have to do the business building things that don’t scale, because it doesn’t feel like work.
